Posts.Content: Apologies! You are absolutely correct in reminding me that I had neglected to post Tom's Gleason score! It is 3=3=6. Here are more specifics (quoted directly from the biopsy report): Diagnosis: A. Prostate, right base, core biopsy Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6 1.4 mm of tumor (7% involvement) in one of one core No perineural invasion identified B. Prostate, right mid, core biopsy Benign prostate tissue, negative for malignancy C. Prostate, right apex, core biopsy Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6 1.0 mm of tumor (4% involvement) in one of two cores No perineural invasion identified D. Prostate, left base, core biopsy Benign prostate tissue, negative for malignancy E. Prostate, left mid, core biopsy Benign prostate tissue, negative for malignancy F. Prostate, left apex, core biopsy Benign prostate tissue, negative for malignancy Clinical information: Elevated PSA (49.1) , right prostate nodule In reading this board, I have come to respect all the information and educated opinions brought here - and certainly welcome any input you might have. We are lucky to live in the Seattle area where some of the best cancer doctors and research are located - specifically the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance - so we feel quite confident in the care that Tom is receiving and the treatment (or non-treatment) suggestions he is given. That said, we realize that a forum can offer the community and collective feedback that we don't get elsewhere. Thanks, all! Carol
Posts.Title: Diary of a Prostate Cancer Wife

Posts.Content: Hello! I have kept a blog for many years - and it has not been a cancer blog. However, this past summer I believed that my blog was about to become a cancer blog... Here is our story. I especially wanted to write it for others who might face an extremely high PSA (49) like we did, in the midst of prostatitis. Although we knew that non-cancerous conditions could cause high PSA scores (like, say, 10 or 20), we were terrified at the score of 49 - especially because we had been so diligent about regular screenings over the past 20 years. I want to post our story so those who find themselves in our circumstances don't have to go through a month of terrified worrying like we did. Here it is: http://www.northwestladybug.com/2014...-book-ill.html Hope this helps someone out there! if so, let me know... Carol

Posts.Title: Diary of a Prostate Cancer Wife

Posts.Content: "The thing that bothers me, though, is that PSA reading." (Chuck) Yes, the PSA was bothersome (and that's an understatement!) to us, as well! As you'll recall from my blog post, Tom had what our PCP called "a raging case of prostatitis" which, it seems, caused his PSA to spike at the very high reading of 49. About three weeks after that PSA test was done (and about five weeks after his symptoms had subsided), he had another one, on the recommendation of the specialist at the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance. (We were told that if the score had not gone down significantly, he wouldn't be a candidate for the AS study.) That reading was 11.89. Just last Wednesday, he had yet another PSA test, this one part of his regular physical. We are anxiously awaiting that score. Our hope and expectation is that it will be lower (albeit likely just slightly lower) than the 11.89 reading. Tom is scheduled for a second biopsy on February 5, 2015, through SCCA. He is extremely nervous because, although he was given general anesthesia for the first biopspy (with another doc), this doctor feels that a general is overkill, er... unwarranted - even for the very nervous, like Tom. He has agreed to prescribe Xanax for the evening before the procedure and Valium for the procedure itself. Tom was so relaxed for the initial biopsy, knowing he'd be out cold ("If you don't knock me out," he joked with the doctor, "I'll knock myself out!"), but I'm quite concerned about this next one, in which he'll be awake. I won't "allow" him to cancel, don't worry! Any words of encouragement and/or wisdom are welcome! Thanks again! Carol
Posts.Title: Diary of a Prostate Cancer Wife
